results.title: Effective Resumes and Job Applications
results.creator_credit: Louise Welsh Schrank, Learning Seed and Stage Fright Productions
results.brief_description: Learn how to handle job applications and resumes so that you don’t make mistakes that could cost you jobs and money. Let this video show you how to handle resumes, cover letters, and job applications. In today’s competitive job market, this video gives straightforward advice you will appreciate.

results.title: Eclair. Episode 09
results.creator_credit: Alma Gray, David Ash, Pat McLagan and ILEA
results.brief_description: The series “Eclair” features Ted, a rather confused and naive Englishman and a pair of mischievous French adolescent twins. The theme in this film is: “Food and drink - a picnic” using a picnic to introduce the viewer to the names of a range of food, food packaging and French shop names.

results.title: Edge of the World
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Bennett, Kim Moodie, Don Featherstone and Film Australia
results.brief_description: This program looks at the important role the ocean and deserts of Western Australia have played in shaping Tim Winton’s values and beliefs, and how the natural world continues to nourish his creativity as a writer. He stresses the place of landscape in his writing, and the important role nature plays as a counterbalance to the less attractive elements of modern civilisation. As we watch him fishing, he recounts his fascination with the monastic tradition and with individuals who are able to successfully survive alone and away from civilisation - an interesting comment in light of his 2001 novel, “Dirt music”. The documentary includes scenes acted from his novel “Cloudstreet”, and extracts from “The Riders”, “Shallows” and “Scission”, read both by Tim Winton and Hugo Weaving.

results.title: Edith Head
results.creator_credit: Charlotte Kerr, Christian Blackwood, Blackwood Productions and Sokal-Kerr Productions
results.brief_description: An interview with multi-award winning costume designer Edith Head in which she discusses her career and presents some of the costumes she has designed for Hollywood legends including Mae West, Jean Harlow, Ginger Rogers, Dorothy Lamour, Paul Newman and Robert Redford. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Ecotoons
results.creator_credit: Claire Breese, Sally Richardson and WWF UK
results.brief_description: Presented by Tony Robinson (Blackadder’s Baldrick), this World Wildlife Fund compilation of 30 international animated shorts is aimed at increasing awareness of environmental issues. Using claymation, stop start animation and computer animation, the tales cover a variety of issues such as pollution, overdevelopment, water and energy conservation, the dumping of toxic waste, recycling, logging, extinction and the depletion of the ozone layer. Also includes footage from the BBC series “Going live” in which a 12 year old viewer won a competition to have her storyboard for a “Morph” episode with a “green” theme brought to animated life by the Aardman studios. She visits Peter Lord at the studios who explains the animation process.

results.title: Eat your greens
results.brief_description: A poignant short film about the tenuous nature of families, as a husband arrives home to his disgruntled wife whose just about to serve dinner. Cast includes Elizabeth Maywald, Alan Cinis, Lauren and Mark Snell.

results.title: Ecology
results.creator_credit: Mal Tennant, Julie Clarke and Sandra Cleary
results.brief_description: Ecology is a far-sighted and exhilirating testament from a diverse but growing community of academics, scientists, futuristic thinkers and philosophers from around the world that points the way to an enlightened tomorrow. Rated: G

results.title: Eat a bowl of tea
results.creator_credit: Wayne Wong, Tom Sternberg, American Playhouse Theatrical Films and Columbia Pictures
results.brief_description: Set between 1949-1951, Wayne Wong’s Capra-style comedy centers on an arranged marriage in New York’s Chinatown. The marriage is a romantic and emotional success until it comes under well-intended but intolerable pressures from the Chinese-American community. The film asks how a young couple can cope when there are few role models at hand and they are isolated from their parents. It also shows the drastic effect of the endless pressure from family and friends to bear children. The tone however remains light, and while broaching serious political and social issues, the film uses laughter rather than anger to highlight these. English and Cantonese dialogue with some English subtitles.
